Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Deciphering the regional-versus-global aspects of the Toarcian (Jurassic) Oceanic Anoxic Event in North America
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Deciphering the regional-versus-global aspects
of the Toarcian (Jurassic) Oceanic Anoxic Event in North America

by

Benjamin Gill, Virginia Tech University, EAR-1324752
Michael Formolo, University of Tulsa, EAR-1324751

ABSTRACT
The geologic record contains many past instances of biological crises linked to environmental change. These events can be thought of as past experiments that offer a window into understanding the dynamics of the current and future Earth surface system. The Oceanic Anoxic Events, or OAEs, of the Mesozoic Era (252 to 65 million years ago) are particularly relevant examples to the present changes on Earth. These intervals are notable because they are characterized by widespread marine anoxia and extinction events. OAEs also occur during times of rapid global warming and large disturbances to the global carbon cycle, thought to be associated with increased levels of greenhouse gases.

The target of this investigation is the oldest of the Mesozoic OAEs -- the Toarcian OAE of the Early Jurassic (approximately 183 million years ago). Past studies of this event have identified major disturbances to the global carbon and sulfur cycles and the occurrence of widespread marine anoxia. However, to date, the majority of these Toarcian OAE studies come from a relatively confined geographical area in Europe. The incomplete Toarcian geochemical record has led to active debates regarding the global nature of both the changes in the element cycles and the geographic extent of marine anoxia. This study will investigate both the inorganic and organic geochemical record of the Toarcian OAE in North American black shales and carbonates to assess the global-versus-regional nature of the event. Further, these new data will be integrated with the available data from Europe in a comprehensive modeling approach that will test the hypothesized mechanisms that triggered, maintained and terminated this event.

This study will have three main broader impact contributions. The first will be the development of graduate students and early career scientists at Virginia Tech and the University of Tulsa. The second will be the development of an educational program through the Museum of Geosciences at Virginia Tech aimed to inform the public about past environmental change on Earth. The Museum of Geosciences offers one of only a few public science venues in the region, and it provides an excellent venue for reaching portions of the population that would not normally be exposed to this science. The last contribution will be the mentorship of undergraduate researchers through the Tulsa Undergraduate Research Challenge (TURC). This program specializes in facilitating research for undergraduate students and community outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anoxic Events:

The geologic record documents many examples of marine extinctions that are linked with increased atmospheric CO2, globally warm temperatures, large shifts in carbon isotopes, and widespread low or lack of oxygen in the oceans (anoxia). In the geologic record, these intervals have characteristically high organic carbon preservation and are often associated with oil and gas reservoirs. These intervals are termed Oceanic Anoxic Events or OAEs.

Much of the previous work on OAEs in the Mesozoic have focused on Europe and the Mediterranean. This project focused on characterization of OAEs expressed in geologic deposits of North America to determine whether and how different locations on Earth experience these global changes.

The primary focus of this work was to characterize the Toarcian (Early Jurassic) aged OAE. The characteristically negative carbon isotope shift was clearly identified in deposits from western Canada, confirming that the Toarcian OAE was a global event. Analysis of organic extracts (biomarkers) from these deposits suggest that they were deposited in anoxic (lacking oxygen) to suboxic (low oxygen) environments. In addition, these biomarkers reveal that salinity and anoxia increased during a portion of the Toarcian. A possible interpretation is that a shift to an arid climate may have promoted evaporation and an increase in salinity, which could have promoted formation of a substantial anoxic zone.

The secondary focus of this project was to characterize and contrast an interval in which anoxia may be episodic: the Mississippian-aged Meramec Formation. These geologic deposits are anomalous in that the relatively high fossil content and low measured total organic carbon (TOC) suggest oxic conditions, while the significant oil and gas found in this formation implies that intervals of anoxia may have occurred. Biomarkers from these samples indicate that the environment of deposition was suboxic, and may have transitioned between a fully marine environment and a marine environment with significant continental input.

Intellectual Merit:

Biological crises recorded in the geologic record are often linked to environmental change, but the specific environmental changes that initiate biotic crises are not well-understood. For example, oceanic anoxic events (OAEs), characterized by widespread marine anoxia and increased organic matter deposition, are often associated with extinction events. OAEs also occur during times of rapid global warming and large disturbances to the global carbon cycle, thought to be associated with increased levels of greenhouse gases. These geologic deposits are a window into understanding the dynamics of the current and future Earth surface system. It is still unclear how OAEs are triggered into global events, how these events effect marine organisms, how OAEs are maintained, and ultimately how OAEs end. More detailed characterizations of OAEs and episodic local anoxic events from this project seek to clarify models of ocean/environmental dynamics.

Broader Impacts:

This study had three main broader impact contributions. The first focus was the development of graduate students and early career scientists at Virginia Tech and the University of Tulsa. The second focus was the development of an educational program through the Museum of Geosciences at Virginia Tech aimed to inform the public about past environmental change on Earth. The last contribution was the mentorship of undergraduate researchers through the TURC program. Three graduate students were supported and trained in sample collection, sample processing, analytical techniques, and data interpretation as a result of this award.
